title: Men stopped from buying £200 of food for homeless in Tesco Brent Cross | Metro News
text:
Tesco stops men purchasing £200 worth of food for the homeless exclusive Ashitha Nagesh for Metro.co.uk Thursday 23 Feb 2017 5:29 pm They were buying £200 worth of food for the homeless (Picture: Facebook/Michael Taub) 
Two men say Tesco stopped them buying food for homeless people – because they were buying ‘too much’. 
Stephen Peter Chamberlain, 70, told Metro.co.uk that he and Jewish faith leader Michael Taub were told not to buy £200 of tinned food for food parcels to give to the needy at Saint Laurence’s Larder in Brent . Mother shares picture of son, 6, just before he died from meningitis 
They were initially stopped by the sales assistant, he said, before the manager got involved – and repeated the claim that they were buying too much food. 
‘I didn’t notice at first, I was still too busy packing the bags,’ Stephen told Metro.co.uk. ‘But then Michael stopped me and said, “We’re not allowed to buy the food”. 
‘When we asked why, the manager said that we were “taking away other customers’ choice”. 
‘I said, “You must have some more tins in the back room. Wouldn’t your shareholders be pleased that you’ve sold hundreds of pounds worth of food?”‘ St Laurence’s Larder in Brent, where Stephen provides food for people in need 
When they told the staff members they were buying the food for a soup kitchen, the manager apparently replied: ‘Well, how do we know that?’ 
Stephen said he was in disbelief. Woman stops brutal gang attack by using her car as a weapon 
‘We’re in a shop, and yet we can’t buy food,’ he said. ‘I know there was a shortage of lettuce the other week, but as far as I know there’s no rationing placed on tinned tuna.’ 
A Tesco spokesperson told Metro.co.uk: ‘We always try to serve all of our customers in the best way and make sure there is availability for everyone. 
‘Sometimes our colleagues have to use their discretion when customers are bulk buying and we apologise for any inconvenience caused for Mr Chamberlain. 
‘We would be keen to see how we can support St Laurence’s Larder and we’ll be in touch to see if they could benefit from our Community Food Connection programme, which links our stores with local charities and community groups to supply them with good quality surplus food.’ More
